instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.S5_PWRGD: What is S5_PWRGD? The S5_PWRGD signal is a status signal that indicates the S5 rails are on and functioning properly. If this is not present, check the S5 rails to see if they are functioning, and the chip that creates S5_PWRGD..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message: 820 00165 no power, board has 2 tiny spots of liquid damage on <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U1930</CHIP>. Magsafe lights, 8.57v on PPBUS. <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is present, when I measure voltage for <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> at L4011 and <RESISTOR>R6414</RESISTOR> I get 0, but when I take a measurement at L4605 I get a reading that jumps all over, very strange. I have replaced <CHIP>U1930</CHIP> due to it looking like shit.

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> present and stable? PPBUS Stable? <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> present?

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message:
Do you get steady 5V at L7520?
What about the other big coils?

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message:
PPBUS 8.57v stable
PPVRTC 3.346 stable
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> 0v
L7520 0v
L7560 3.347v

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message:
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>?
If not, check <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL>.
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing at least?
L7520 should pulse at same time.
If yes, check if other coils pulse too.
Is better to check toggling <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal; use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads for this...

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.346v stable
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> 0V no pulsing at least that I can seen on my Fluke, I dont have a scope
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> 3.427v stable

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message:
"Is better to check toggling <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> signal; use <RESISTOR>R5115</RESISTOR>/16 pads for this..."
You need to see any reaction.

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message: 2info, I dont understand what you are asking me to do. Are you telling me to short the pads?

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message: Exactly, like pressing power button...

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message: Yeah, unfortunately im still getting no change bridging those pads.

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWRMEN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>.
Does MLB start on SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>S5_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.399v
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> 3.426v
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWRMEN</SIGNAL> 3.248v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> 3.426v
<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.343v
Not sure what you mean by SMC bypass mode, but I cant get this board to do anything as far as turning on.

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message: Press power button, connect charger and maintain pressing 5-10s...

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message: With SMC bypass i get about 2 seconds of fan spin, then nothing after that.

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message:
"i get about 2 seconds of fan spin"
That means L7520 gets voltage in this time.
Check which other big coils get voltage...

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message:
At least L7520 must get 5V, if fan spins!
So check voltages in these 2 seconds...

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message: L7520 is not getting 5v, for those 2 seconds that the fan spins, I get a different voltage each time it comes on anywhere between .855-4.3v

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message:
So L7520 pulses; you can see 5V with o-scope, not DC multimeter.
Check which other coils pulse too...
Also check if <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> pulsing?

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message: <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> does not seem to be pulsing, unfortunately I do not have an o scope

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message:
A DC multimeter should be good enough.
You will not catch the nominal voltage expected, but can see if pulse.
Just toggle <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> repeatedly...

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message: I will try again, I know sometimes it takes a few trys, but I literally connected and wiggled those pads probably 50 times the other day.

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message: Solder a wire on <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> pad and touch the ground (any metal plate of chassis), to simulate power button...

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message: I have tried to short the pads with multiple tools, have soldered a wire, nothing is happening toggling <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>

threads.title: 820 00165 No Power
threads.message:
Check for pulse on all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SX_L</SIGNAL> signals.
Strange to get pulsing only L7520...
